text: You can get a random integer in a specific range from Java's Random class by calling the nextInt(int n) method.
For example,

code:
Random rand = new Random();
int a = rand.nextInt(7);

text: will give you a random integer >= 0 and < 7.
This isn't exactly the same as randrange in Python, but you could use it as the index to an array of objects, or as the value of a roll of a single die.
Randrange can be replaced by methods in java.util.Random.
Like Python, Java has an extensive standard library which you should reference.
I'd recommend that you look up the docs on randrange().
Once you know exactly what it does, google for the those keywords, plus the word Java.
One thing you'll quickly discover in working with languages is that the APIs can be very different.
There might not be an equivalent of randrange in Java, but you might be able to find two or three functions that you can combine to do the same thing.
